docs.lead_paragraph: ALTHOUGH Nassau County has adopted an ordinance to outlaw ''head shops,'' and Suffolk County is considering a similar measure, the constitutionality of barring the sale of drug paraphernalia remains in doubt. At its last meeting, the Nassau County Board of Supervisors unanimously approved an amendment to the county's administrative code that would make it a crime to sell drug-related goods. The law would provide a maximum $1,000 fine and/or one year in jail for anyone who ''knowingly and unlawfully sells or displays for the purpose of sale any drug paraphernalia,'' including such items as cocaine spoons, graters to process marijuana, the paper to roll a cigarette, and the ''roach,'' or electrical wire clip, to hold the cigarette. The new law was scheduled to take effect within 60 days, by Dec. by 19, barring any legal challenge like those brought against a similar state law and a Westchester County law on which the Nassau law was based.
